metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydro-meteorological observation network (automatic weather station of Bajitan Gobi Desert Station, 2014)
metadata.description:
The data set contains the observation data of meteorological elements from the Bajitan Gobi Desert Station, which is located along the middle reaches of the Heihe Hydro-meteorological Observation Network, and the data set covers data from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014. The station is located in Bajitan, West Zhangye City, Gansu Province, the underlying surface is Gobi. The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 100.3042E, 38.9150N, and the altitude is 1562m. The air temperature and relative humidity sensors are erected 5 and 10 meters above the ground, facing North; the barometer is installed 2 meters above the ground; tipping bucket rain gauge is installed 10 meters above the ground; the wind speed sensors are set 5 and 10 meters above the ground, facing North; the four-component radiometer is installed 6 meters above the ground, facing South; two infrared thermometers are installed 6 meters above the ground, facing South, and the probe orientation is vertical downward; the soil temperature probes are buried respectively at 0cm on the ground surface, 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm under the ground, they are located 2 meters from the meteorological tower in the North. The soil moisture sensors are buried 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm under the ground, 2 meters from the meteorological tower in the South; the soil heat flow boards (3 pieces) are buried 6cm under the ground. 
Observed items include: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5m、RH_5m、Ta_10m、RH_10m) (unit: Celsius, percentage), pressure(Press) (unit:hectopascal), precipitation (Rain) (unit: mm), wind speed (WS_5m、WS_10m) (unit: meter / sec), wind direction (WD_10m) (unit: degree), four-component radiation (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (unit: watt / square meter), surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit: Celsius) , soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (unit: watt / square meter), soil moisture (Ms_2cm、Ms_4cm、Ms_10cm、Ms_20cm、Ms_40cm、Ms_60cm、Ms_100cm) (unit: volumetric water content, percentage), soil temperature (Ts_0cm、Ts_2cm、Ts_4cm、Ts_10cm、Ts_20cm、Ts_40cm、Ts_60cm、Ts_100cm) (unit : Celsius).
Processing and quality control of observation data: (1) Ensure 144 data per day (every 10 minutes), if there is missing data, it is marked as -6999. Due to sensor problem, Ms_40cm data between January 1 and March 2 had a large fluctuation, it can only be used as reference. (2) Eliminate moments with duplicate records; (3) Remove data that is significantly beyond physical meaning or beyond the measuring range of the instrument; (4) Data marked by red is debatable; (5) The formats of the date and time are uniform, and the date and time are in the same column. For example, the time is: 2014-6-10 10:30; (6) The naming rule is: AWS + site name.
For hydro-meteorological network or site information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018). For observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al. (2011).

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Sensible heat flux (H) is a significant component of land surface water and energy balance determinations. There are several methods for measuring surface water and heat fluxes, such as eddy covariance (EC) and Bowen ratio systems. For large-scale H, remote sensing (RS)-based observations are useful. RS instruments themselves cannot directly measure H. Therefore, methods for validating RS inversion products are critical for using such products. Since the 1990s, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has been widely applied to measure sensible heat flux around the world, and it has also been used to validate RS estimations owing to the large scale of its measurements.
research objective: In this study, a weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) model is proposed to convert EC-scale H to LAS-scale H. It involves path-weighting functions of EC and LAS source areas in both regression and area kriging stages.
challenges: However, methods of converting one H scale to another to validate RS products are still open for question. The method does not consider the path-weighting function in the EC- to LAS-scale kriging with the regression residue, which inevitably brought about a bias estimation.
methods: In the kernel area, 18 EC system sets were installed for the experiment, 17 of which were used in this study. Observations and footprints of the 17 EC and four LAS groups between 12:00 and 12:30 BST (Beijing Standard Time) were averaged to obtain a mean value when the atmosphere stability was under unstable conditions with high turbulent fluxes. By considering the wind direction, the wind speeds were decomposed into north and east components (WS), and then weighted averages were calculated with the corresponding EC and LAS footprint weights. After abstracting FVC, NDVI, LST, and WS with the footprint models, nine regression models were built for each of the periods based on the proposed multiple linear regression model. The four independent variables were also abstracted for the four LAS footprints. The residual part of LAS H is then estimated from the 17 EC H residuals by the above WATA kriging model.
dataset: Four groups of LAS (two sets in each group) were installed in 3 × 3 and 2 × 1 MODIS pixels. In the kernel area, 18 EC system sets were installed for the experiment, 17 of which were used in this study. There are also 17 automatic weather station sets (including a super-station) installed in the field. Nine observations (06/15, 06/24, 07/10, 08/02, 08/11, 08/18, 08/27, 09/03, and 09/12) made between June and September 2012 were selected for this study. Synchronous ASTER RS products at 12:15 BST were downloaded from the US—National Aeronautics and Space Administration and processed according to Zhou et al. [26] and Bastiaanssen et al. [27], including the Land Surface Temperature (LST) [26], Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), and Fractional Vegetation Cover (FVC) [27].
findings: Results show that WATA RK outperforms traditional methods in most cases, improving estimation accuracy. The method is considered to provide an efficient validation of RS H flux products.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a multiscale data collection method used to study eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Example.Answer: The HiWATER experiment utilized instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including a sparse network of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in the data collection process for hydrometeorological observations in arid regions?
Example.Answer: One challenge is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, as highlighted in the HiWATER experiment.

Definition.Question: What are the key components of a hydrometeorological observation network in arid regions?
Definition.Answer: A hydrometeorological observation network in arid regions typically includes automatic meteorological stations measuring air temperature, wind speed, humidity, radiation, and turbulent fluxes. It may also include soil moisture sensors, soil heat flux plates, eddy covariance systems, large aperture scintillometers, and various remote sensing instruments like LiDAR and thermal imagers.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with measuring evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with measuring evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes include accurately estimating surface fluxes due to the mixture of soil and vegetation, managing the complexity of model parameters, handling uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences, and accounting for the effects of strong advective environments.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the spatial and temporal scales of observations between the AWS-based data collection method and the HiWATER experiment's multi-scale observation system?
Comparison.Answer: The AWS-based method provides continuous hydrometeorological data with a high temporal resolution of every 10 minutes at specific locations, whereas the HiWATER experiment covers multiple scales including regional observations with airborne remote sensing and a network of flux towers, offering a broader spatial scale.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can multi-scale data acquisition enhance the interpretation of eco-hydrological interactions in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Multi-scale data acquisition, involving various instruments such as eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing devices, enables comprehensive observation of eco-hydrological processes across different scales. This approach facilitates a detailed interpretation of oasis-desert interactions, providing insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics critical for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately measuring evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes using remote sensing methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in accurately measuring evapotranspiration (ET) in heterogeneous landscapes using remote sensing methods stem from factors such as the complexity of the two-source energy balance models, errors in the derived component temperatures due to image classification errors, and uncertainties in measuring soil and canopy component temperatures. Additionally, the strong advective environments and incomplete energy balance closure with respect to available energy can further complicate accurate ET measurement.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are multiscale observations crucial for understanding eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Multiscale observations are crucial for understanding eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems because these systems are characterized by their complexity and heterogeneity. The poor availability of multiscale data has historically hindered progress in this field. By capturing data at multiple scales, researchers can better understand interactions within the oasis-desert ecosystem and address the challenges of scaling up observations to larger areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes difficulties in validating remote sensing products for sensible heat flux measurement?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Difficulties in validating remote sensing products for sensible heat flux measurement are caused by the challenges in converting the scale of measurements from eddy covariance (EC) systems to large aperture scintillometers (LAS). Traditional methods do not account for path-weighting functions in the kriging process, leading to biases. Moreover, the inherent difference in the scale of measurements between ground-based EC systems and remote sensing observations adds to the complexity and potential for errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of applying a weighted area-to-area regression kriging model to convert EC-scale data to LAS-scale data for validating remote sensing products?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying a weighted area-to-area regression kriging model to convert EC-scale data to LAS-scale data can improve the accuracy of validation for remote sensing products. This method accounts for spatial variability and path-weighting functions, which can lead to more reliable validation of sensible heat flux estimates and enhance the utility of remote sensing data in large-scale environmental monitoring.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of employing a multiscale observation system to capture eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals of employing a multiscale observation system are to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogenous surfaces by capturing data at hierarchically nested scales. This approach aims to provide a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas to support ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of developing a model to convert eddy covariance-scale sensible heat flux to large aperture scintillometer-scale measurements?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of developing such a model is to improve the validation of remote sensing products by accurately converting smaller scale measurements to larger scale measurements. This conversion helps in reducing bias and increasing the estimation accuracy of sensible heat flux, which is a significant component of land surface water and energy balance determinations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed in converting eddy covariance-scale sensible heat flux (H) to large aperture scintillometer-scale H for remote sensing validation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) model is proposed to convert EC-scale H to LAS-scale H. This model involves path-weighting functions of EC and LAS source areas in both regression and area kriging stages. Observations and footprints of EC and LAS systems are averaged to obtain mean values under unstable atmospheric conditions with high turbulent fluxes. The method involves multiple linear regression models with variables abstracted for LAS footprints and estimates the LAS H residual from EC H residuals using the WATA RK model.

Enablement.Question: What are the technological advancements that have enabled the integration of multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection in eco-hydrological studies?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the use of hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation, including flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers have enabled the integration of multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection in eco-hydrological studies.

Enablement.Question: How do path-weighting functions contribute to the conversion of eddy covariance data to large aperture scintillometer scale data?
Enablement.Answer: Path-weighting functions contribute to the conversion by accounting for the source area differences between eddy covariance (EC) and large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data. This involves using the functions in both regression and area kriging stages, which helps to improve the estimation accuracy of scaling EC-scale sensible heat fluxes to LAS-scale.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the use of thermal infrared cameras improve the accuracy of energy balance models in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: Thermal infrared cameras improve the accuracy by providing high-resolution measurements of soil and canopy component temperatures, which are crucial for estimating evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration. These measurements help refine energy balance models by providing better validation of component temperatures against observed ratios and enabling accurate separation of latent heat fluxes.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of multiscale observations in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in ensuring accuracy and reliability of multiscale observations include the poor availability of multiscale observations and the complex instrumentation required at hierarchically nested scales to capture eco-hydrological processes. These challenges are addressed by using a combination of ground-based measurements and remote sensing technologies, as seen in the HiWATER experiment.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected difficulties in validating remote sensing products for sensible heat flux measurements, and how might these be addressed?
Expectation.Answer: The expected difficulties in validating remote sensing products for sensible heat flux include the inability of remote sensing instruments to directly measure heat fluxes and the challenge of converting flux measurements from small to large scales. These issues are often addressed by implementing methods like weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) and using multiple linear regression models based on footprint models.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be critical to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development, and what data collection strategies could support this goal?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is critical for ecological stability and socioeconomic development in arid regions. This requires understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in these ecosystems. Long-term observational datasets, including turbulent flux data, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters, are crucial to support these goals and are collected using a combination of automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, and scintillometers.

Judgmental.Question: How effectively do you think the integration of ground-based measurements and remote sensing can address the challenges of data scarcity in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of ground-based measurements and remote sensing is promising for addressing data scarcity in heterogeneous landscapes. It combines the detail and accuracy of ground-based observations with the extensive coverage of remote sensing. The use of techniques like the TSEB model, which leverages both types of data, suggests improved accuracy in measuring evapotranspiration and energy fluxes. However, challenges remain, such as the need for accurate temperature measurements and the validation of remote sensing products.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the reliability of datasets obtained from multi-scale observation systems in capturing oasis-desert interactions?
Judgmental.Answer: Datasets from multi-scale observation systems are quite reliable for capturing oasis-desert interactions, especially when they incorporate diverse data sources like eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing. These systems provide a comprehensive view of the eco-hydrological processes. However, the reliability can be affected by factors such as sensor calibration, data processing, and quality control challenges.

Judgmental.Question: Do you believe that the current methodologies for converting eddy covariance scale measurements to larger scales adequately support remote sensing validation?
Judgmental.Answer: Current methodologies, such as the weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) model, show promise in converting eddy covariance scale measurements to larger scales for remote sensing validation. These methods improve estimation accuracy by considering path-weighting functions. However, there are still challenges in ensuring unbiased estimations, suggesting that further refinement and testing in different environmental conditions may be necessary to fully support remote sensing validation.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection for hydrometeorological observations can be standardized across different oasis-desert ecosystems?
Assertion.Answer: Data collection for hydrometeorological observations in oasis-desert ecosystems involves using automatic weather stations and eddy covariance systems. These systems capture data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature, air temperature, humidity gradients, wind speed, and air pressure in a standardized format over a set period. The observations are then subjected to quality control processes involving data calibration, collection, processing, and archiving, which ensure consistency across different environments.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how datasets from remote sensing instruments can effectively validate surface water and heat flux measurements?
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing instruments, while useful for large-scale observations, cannot directly measure variables such as sensible heat flux. Validation of these measurements typically involves methods like using large aperture scintillometers (LAS) to validate RS inversion products. A weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) model is often used to convert data from smaller-scale eddy covariance (EC) measurements to larger LAS scales, ensuring more accurate validation of remote sensing data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the challenges associated with converting small-scale hydrological data to larger scales for remote sensing validation, and suggest potential solutions to these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in converting small-scale hydrological data to larger scales for remote sensing validation include bias estimation due to the lack of path-weighting functions in the kriging process, leading to inaccuracies. To address these challenges, a weighted area-to-area regression kriging model can be used, which integrates path-weighting functions in both regression and area kriging stages. This approach helps in better alignment between different scales and improves estimation accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets or data collection approaches to improve understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis–desert ecosystems, emphasizing multiscale observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets to improve understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis–desert ecosystems include multiscale data obtained from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) project. This includes a combination of flux observation matrices from eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, as well as hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data using LiDAR and imaging spectrometers. The datasets encompass energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, and auxiliary hydrometeorological data. Multiscale observation periods, such as intensive observation periods and continuous data collection over several years, provide comprehensive insights into these systems.
